benchmark_config.jira_title: Implement/Test API: PUT /1.0/kb/accounts/{accountId}/customFields - Modify custom fields to account

covered: PUT Valid Request: Multiple success paths update custom fields and return 204 (TC01, TC02, TC03, TC04, TC15, TC16, TC17, TC24).
PUT Non-Existing Resource: Error when accountId is invalid format and when account does not exist (TC06, TC07).
Validation and Error Handling: Missing required header, missing body, malformed JSON, invalid schema (TC08, TC09, TC10, TC11).
Security/Robustness: SQLi/XSS inputs rejected (TC20, TC21); unsupported headers ignored (TC05).
Performance/Limits: Large array and near-maximum payload size, including 413 on exceed (TC04, TC26).
Server/Network Failures: 401 unauthorized, 502 dependency failure, 503 service down, 504 timeout, and retry on transient errors (TC12, TC14, TC13, TC19, TC22).
Edge-case semantics: Empty array removes all fields; extra properties ignored; max lengths accepted (TC15, TC17, TC16).
Integration: Audit logging and external reporting reflect updates (TC27, TC28).
gaps: PUT Partial Update semantics: No scenario clarifies whether PUT merges vs replaces the full set when only a subset of fields is provided. There is no test ensuring partial updates are rejected unless allowed.
Concurrency on same resource: No scenarios for two concurrent PUTs to the same account testing race conditions, last-write-wins, or optimistic locking/versioning behavior.

Response headers/content negotiation: Story mentions produces application/json, but 204 responses typically have no body. No checks for Content-Type, absence of body, or relevant headers (e.g., Date, request-id).
Idempotency: No tests verifying that repeating the same PUT request yields the same state and response (idempotent behavior expected for PUT).
Error code consistency: Non-existent account returns 400 in tests; confirm/cover expected code (often 404) per API contract and add scenario accordingly.

Schema contract depth: No explicit tests validating required CustomField fields and allowed enum/value ranges beyond a generic invalid schema case (e.g., key/name/value constraints, duplicates behavior under success path).
Authorization breadth: Only 401 covered; no coverage for 403 (authenticated but not authorized) if applicable to this endpoint.
recommendations: Add explicit Partial Update scenarios: one where only a subset of existing fields is sent and assert the contract (replace-all vs merge). If merges are not allowed, expect 400; if allowed, verify correct merge semantics.
Introduce concurrency tests on the same account: two near-simultaneous PUTs with different payloads; validate deterministic outcome, data consistency, and any version/conflict handling.
Verify idempotency: Send the exact same PUT twice and assert the state and status code remain consistent (204 both times, no duplicate effects).
Add response header checks: Ensure 204 has no body, appropriate Content-Type behavior, and any required headers (e.g., request-id, correlation-id).
Clarify and test non-existent resource error code per spec (400 vs 404). Add a scenario for the expected status and message.

Expand schema validation: Add scenarios for field-level constraints (e.g., allowed characters, max/min length per field, allowed/required keys), and one for duplicate names under success if the system supports overwriting vs rejecting.
Extend authorization coverage if applicable: Add 403 forbidden for users lacking permissions even with valid auth.
Document and test audit metadata propagation: Verify X-Killbill-Reason and X-Killbill-Comment are persisted/visible in audit logs, not just that a 204 is returned.
